scenes.background: You are leading a project team that has just received an urgent assignment requiring a significant amount of work to be completed within a tight deadline. The team is feeling a lot of pressure, and morale is low, with some members showing signs of frustration and anxiety. One of the team members, Alex, said, 'This is impossible! We can't get this done in time.' You suggested taking a short break and coming back with a fresh perspective. [Monica] agreed, but [Bob] still seemed skeptical. After the break, [Bob] said, 'Even with a break, I don't see how we're going to manage this.' [Monica] added, 'Yeah, we need a better plan or more resources.' You acknowledged the team's concerns and suggested breaking down the tasks into smaller pieces and assigning them based on everyone's strengths. Now, [Monica] is looking over the task breakdown, and [Bob] is still frowning. You encouraged the team to stay focused and take a step-by-step approach. [Monica] seems a bit more optimistic, but [Bob] is still doubtful. [Bob] said, 'Even with this step-by-step approach, it still feels overwhelming. What if we're just setting ourselves up for failure?' You suggested reassessing the strategy and considering more time if needed. [Monica] nodded in agreement, but [Bob] still looks concerned. [Bob] says, 'I just don't think we have enough resources or time to pull this off successfully.'
scenes.description: [Monica] responds, 'Maybe we should list out exactly what we need and see if we can get more help or allocate our time better.'

options.text: That's a good idea, Monica. Let's make a detailed list and see where we can get additional support.
options.analysis: You acknowledged Monica's suggestion and proposed a practical solution, demonstrating empathy and good social skills.
